question_sentence: Which country did Vladimir Putin visit immediately after his much-vaunted trip to North Korea?
evidence: Putin touched down in Hanoi after his state visit to North Korea, hoping to strengthen Russia's historical ties with communist-ruled Vietnam. He follows Joe Biden and Xi Jinping, who have both visited the country in the past year.

question_sentence: The Boston Celtics beat which team in the NBA Finals, securing their 18th championship triumph?
evidence: Boston won 106-88 against the Mavericks in Game 5 of the NBA Finals, giving them a record 18th NBA title and a first championship since 2008.

question_sentence: "House of the Dragon" returned to our screens for a second season this week. What was the title of episode one?
evidence: The season two premiere of the "Game of Thrones" spin-off met with praise from critics, with The Guardian's Rebecca Nicholson calling it "unmissable and thrilling television".

question_sentence: Recent research suggests that new fathers experience what kind of brain changes?
evidence: Brain imaging revealed that, like new mothers, "men experienced a reduction in grey matter before and after they became fathers". Shrinking grey matter "might fine-tune the brain to work more efficiently" and foster a closer bond between father and child.

question_sentence: Which French footballer used a pre-Euros press conference to urge his compatriots to reject "extremes" at the upcoming election?
evidence: Jordan Bardella, leader of the far-right National Rally, said "multimillionaires" should not lecture "people who can no longer make ends meet". Find out more on this week's episode of The Week Unwrapped podcast.

question_sentence: Louisiana enacted a law requiring all public schools to display what inside classrooms?
choices: A statue of the state's bird
evidence: Louisiana Governor Jeff Landry signed a law on Wednesday requiring all public school classrooms to display the Ten Commandments. Louisiana is the first state to mandate such displays since a similar Kentucky law was struck down in 1980.

question_sentence: Newly released documents revealed that Amazon's Rekognition AI, which can read emotions, has been trialled where?
evidence: Internal documents from Network Rail, which manages the UK's rail infrastructure, detail trials of the AI software in several stations, including London Euston and Manchester Piccadilly, and said it could be used to assess "customer satisfaction".

question_sentence: What is the name of the rare genetic variant associated with delaying the onset of Alzheimer's disease?
evidence: The APOE3 gene, also known as the Christchurch variant, can potentially delay the onset of cognitive decline and dementia by approximately five years. A study found that 27 relatives with just one Christchurch gene developed symptoms roughly five years later than other family members with the early-onset genetic mutation.

question_sentence: According to new biography "The House of Beckham", cost-conscious David Beckham served £2.99 bottles of which wine at a Unicef fundraiser?
evidence: Tom Bower's book also includes claims that Victoria expensed bags of Marks & Spencer's crisps, and David left a Hard Rock Cafe without leaving a tip – supposedly prompting his alleged mistress Rebecca Loos to go public with details of their affair.

question_sentence: Which country did not attend the two-day Ukraine peace summit in Switzerland?
evidence: Russia was not invited to the peace talks and China, Moscow's most important ally, did not attend the two-day Ukraine summit, during which 78 countries signed a communique supporting Ukraine's territorial integrity.

question_sentence: Which movie is considered to be the first summer blockbuster?
evidence: Released on June 20, 1975, “Jaws” went on the become the first film to gross more than $100 million at the box office.

question_sentence: Summer is peak season for amusement parks. Where was America’s first roller coaster built?
evidence: The first roller coaster in the US opened on Coney Island in Brooklyn, New York, in 1884.

question_sentence: America’s most famous eating contest takes place annually on July 4. Which food is devoured at the competition?
evidence: Nathan's Famous International Hot Dog Eating contest is held on July 4. Notably, 16-time champion Joey Chestnut will not compete in this year’s event after he struck a deal with a rival plant-based food company.

question_sentence: Fireworks have been a part of every July 4th celebration in the US since the first in 1777. Which country is considered to be the birthplace of fireworks?
evidence: Most historians credit China with the invention of fireworks around 800 AD. But it was in the 1830s that Italian inventors added trace amounts of metals to the mix and created the colorful displays that dazzle us now.

question_sentence: Summer is also state fair season. Which state fair is the largest in the US?
evidence: The State Fair of Texas welcomed more than 2.3 million visitors in 2023. While the Iowa State Fair is not the largest, it is a traditional stomping ground for politicians.

question_sentence: Watermelon is a popular summertime treat. About what percentage of a watermelon is water?
evidence: The average watermelon is about 92% water. For your next summer gathering, these three tips can help you determine if that watermelon you've grabbed at the store will be ripe or not.

question_sentence: Summer is a great time to hit the beach. Which state is known as The Ocean State?
evidence: The Ocean State is the official nickname of Rhode Island. While Rhode Island is the smallest state in the union, it boasts some 400 miles of shoreline.

question_sentence: Drive-in movies were a popular summer pastime in the ‘50s and ‘60s. When did the first drive-in movie theater open in the US?
evidence: The Camden Drive-In in Camden, New Jersey, opened in June of 1933. The price of admission was 25 cents for the car and 25 cents per person.

question_sentence: The summer travel rush is in full-swing with massive crowds passing through airports. How many scheduled flights do US airlines offer each day?
evidence: US carriers are offering more than 26,000 scheduled flights each day this summer — up nearly 1,400 a day from summer 2023, according to Airlines for America.

question_sentence: Which holiday is considered the “unofficial end of summer” in the US?
evidence: For many, Labor Day symbolizes the end of summer. The federal holiday, celebrated on the first Monday in September, honors working people and their contributions to society.

question_sentence: Who won the Eagles Autism Challenge 5K?
Which of the following venomous creatures are native to Delaware?
What is the significant change in the Big Fish Restaurant Group after partnering with the Baltimore-based lifestyle hospitality group, Atlas?
choices: All Big Fish locations will be closed.
Big Fish Restaurant Group will continue as usual and all employees will be retained.
Big Fish Restaurant Group will stop its operations.

question_sentence: What TV comedy features stars now promoting Four Walls Irish American Whiskey?
What event took place at President Joe Biden’s campaign headquarters in Wilmington?
What is the main concern of the Milford school board’s proposed policy change?
choices: A. To ensure all learning environments are free from content that could create an intimidating, hostile, or offensive educational environment.
B. To ban all political symbols and flags in the classroom.
D. To allow students to express their political or religious beliefs freely.

question_sentence: What is the purpose of the Fire Grants and Safety Act?
choices: To provide funding for the construction of new fire departments in Delaware.
To provide funding for the development and deployment of new carbon-free nuclear technologies.
To impose a fire protection fee on properties in Delaware.

question_sentence: What significant milestones would Lisa Blunt Rochester achieve if she wins the U.S. Senate race?
choices: She would be the first woman to represent Delaware in the Senate.
She would be the first Black person to represent Delaware in the Senate.

question_sentence: What is the definition of a heat wave according to the National Weather Service?
choices: A period of abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days, dependent on humidity and covering small areas
A period of abnormally hot weather lasting more than two days, not dependent on humidity and covering large areas.
A period of abnormally cold weather lasting more than two days, not dependent on humidity and covering large areas.

question_sentence: What significant event did the Delaware Juneteenth Association organize to kick off the observance of Juneteenth in 2024?
